The Related Discourses

(Skt. Saṃyukta Āgama; Ch. 雜阿含經)

The Related Disources was translated to Chinese by Guṇabhadra and Baoyun sometime between 435-443 CE. The text as it has survived in the Taisho Daizokyo consists of 1,362 individually numbered sutras, although the numbering of abbreviated sutras is inconsistent (i.e., if they are all counted, the number is larger). The text spans 50 fascicles and 373 pages of Taisho volume 2.

The Pali equivalent is the Saṃyutta Nikāya (SN), and the two collections do overlap extensively. Unlike its Pali counterpart, however, the Related Discourses lacks explicit subdivisions. Indeed, the original Chinese text lacked subdivisions, sutra titles, or even numbers. Nonetheless, careful reading and comparisons to the Pali show that it did consist of thematically arranged groups of sutras, similar to SN but in a different arrangement.

Below is a list of the English translations currently available with brief synopses of their contents. Pali equivalents are listed in () and the sourcetext is indicated in [].

Note: All titles for SA sutras are supplied by the translator as an aid for the reader. They are not in the original Chinese. The sutras are numbered according to the Taisho, adding letters (e.g. 800a) when numbering abbreviated sutras the Taisho skipped.

The Path (cf. SN 45: Maggasaṃyutta)

SA 748: The First Sign (SN 45.55: Accomplishment in Proper Attention (1st) ) [T 99.198b5]

Right view is the first sign of liberation like the first light of dawn is the first sign of sunrise.

SA 749: The Pārijāta Tree (AN 7.69: The Shady Orchid Tree) [T 26.422a18]

The Buddha relates the seasonal cycle of the mythical pārijāta tree in the Trāyastriṃśa Heaven and compares it to a monk's progress towards liberation.

SA 750: The City Parable (AN 7.67: The Simile of the Citadel) [T 26.422c09]

The Buddha employs an analogy of a border city's defenses and supplies to describe the qualities and meditative abilities that lead a disciple to liberation.

SA 751: The Water Parable (AN 7.15: A Simile With Water) [T 26.424a13]

The Buddha reinterprets a common simile of a person who progressively gets a footing in a river and wades to shore. He relates it to the way a disciple overcomes spiritual obstacles and progresses to liberation.

SA 752: The Wood Pile Parable (AN 7.72: The Simile of the Bonfire) [T 26.425a15]

The Buddha warns a group of newly ordained monks about the dangers of giving into short-term pleasures that will lead to their downfall. He uses a series of descriptions of the punishments suffered in hell to drive home the point that what that seems pleasant can lead to torment in the future if one is not careful.

SA 753: The Good Person’s Departure (AN 7.55: Places People Are Reborn) [T 26.427a13]

The Buddha gives a series of cryptic descriptions of seven ways a non-returner disciple eventually attains liberation after leaving this world.

SA 754: Worldly Merit [T 26.427c25]

The Buddha describes the worldly and transcendent merits that can be cultivated by the faithful. The worldly merits come from giving material support and service to the monasteries. The transcendent merits come from seeking to learn the teachings and accepting the precepts.
